text:
"Captain!" $HeOrShe sneezes uncontrollably as you come close. There's a moment as you maneuver yourself to be just out of range of the river of snot and alcohol dribbling down the front of $hisOrHer face and onto the floor.

To be sick, crying, and drunk is not the best of combinations, to put it lightly.

"Mind if you help me find my ship?" $HeOrShe sneezes again, and out of the corner of your eye, you notice your bodyguards take two steps back.

"Ah. Right." $HeOrShe sniffles. "I had this most lovely ship. I called her The Luminary, because she was my light in the darkness. Me and her, so many journeys we've had together... ah."

You wait patiently for the poor fellow to blow through another round of Tri-Tachyon branded tissues. "Sorry, captain. It's just... Pirates! Pirates struck down my pride and joy, and now for all I know it's a pile of scrap in their cursed holds. So... if you would do me a favour and find out what happened to 'er, I'd at least have some sense of closure."

"It was a routine survey mission. The Luminary was perfect for the job, of course. She was an Apogee-class cruiser, and she'd seen her fair share of battles. So had I, but... those pirates. Normally, a fleet of their size'd be too slow to catch us, but they caught us by surprise as we were jumping in."

"We were too close to run, so we fought. It took us losing half the surveying fleet before we could disengage, and make a break for it. We e-burned away in a panic, and the pirates... sustained burn. Can you believe that?"

The outcome was obvious. The pirate fleet caught up eventually to the panicked survey fleet and managed to defeat the rest of the fleet in a second engagement. It was, as $heOrShe puts it, "a hopeless battle".

"I was lucky enough to escape that second fight on a Dram as it were, captain. Might have been the cowardice, luck, or both, but at least I'm here to tell the tale."

text:
You convene your senior officers to discuss the option of seizing The Luminary outright. Initial queries from your crew to the local authorities are rebuffed, but simple visual observation from orbit easily identifies The Luminary sitting in one of the spaceports. From there, it's not hard to figure out that the pirates are intentionally showing off their prize... and preparing for what your crew believe to be certain "special modifications".

Ship hijacking operations have been done before, and initial plans are drafted based on past occurrences. Projections estimate the operation will require only a fair amount of marines ending in only light casualties. Assuming, of course, that extraction is complete before local security elements can properly activate in response.

The plan your officers decided on involved, of course, the art of surprise.

Marine squads arrive slowly onto the port concourse disguised as unsuspecting crew looking to unload and unwind. All manage to snake their way towards the docking bays where The Luminary is held, but stop short of entering the particular section where your prize is stored. Tactical teams discreetly take their time preparing charges, taking positions, and coordinating with targeting feeds onboard your $shipOrFleet.

Chaos breaks out instantly the moment your tac lead gives the go-ahead, and what counts for security is quickly overwhelmed in a burst of flashes. A squad of marines rush into the Apogee and are met with additional gunfire, comms crackling as your marines find themselves fighting for control both inside the ship and out in the docking bay as the first of local security begin to pour in earlier than expected.

Bridge crew execute EW solutions as marines simultaneously toss out smoke charges in an attempt to buy time. Marines onboard The Luminary are forced into clearing the ship room-by-room, but all it takes is a squad to reach the bridge and initiate take-off procedures for the rest of the raid team to begin withdrawing by way of the ship itself.

With station-side security unable to do more than leave a few scorch marks on the Apogee as it links up with your $shipOrFleet, the outcome is obvious. 

Complete success.

"We're damned lucky they kept the ship doors open," the tac lead reports to you in the later debriefing. "But the job's done, eh?"

There's a moment as you watch the acrid plasma markings dotting their power armour undersuit visibly smoke on the comms-feed. Better for you that they're currently on The Luminary rather than with you on the flagship, maybe. Certainly for your nose at least.

It's seconds later when your sensors officer shouts in alarm: it seems several station batteries have come online and are swivelling towards the general direction of your fleet.

There's a long speech about the expenses and time investment required to support the now impoverished, needy communities of traumatised citizens of the Persean Sector. Truly, it is a privilege to be able to support these people through these trying times, and there is no doubt that their name will be remembered for days to come should their promises come to fruition.

Unfortunately, as the charitable individual you are, there is but only a limited amount of funding you can allocate to the various causes throughout the sector, and 50,000 is all you can spare. But there is hope! Already, your crew are sending along vast data packages filled to the brink with strategies and the helplines needed to bring all those affected out of the abyss of despair and towards a brand new dawn that is the future, for what future could there be but one where you hand over 50,000 credits in exchange for one Apogee?

"Pretty, eh? Bought it at a deep discount, I'll tell you. Bit bland as it stands, so I think the boys can spice it up a notch." $HeOrShe brings up a live feed of the 'decorating', where you find a crowd of spectators watching oiled men crack bottles of slime against the hull while a half-dozen cranes operate strange makeshift devices from above.

"Ach, okay. I'll admit it. When they offered to decorate, I said yeah because they're all going to die in a dozen cycles or two, right? So go hog wild, have fun before we bury you in Ludd's embrace. And, well, I was expecting something... cooler. From them. You know? Like the Mk. II variants we have for some of the other ships. Not this." They halfheartedly gesture with a hand. 

You have to admit, The Luminary might be a little more pink and glittery than anyone ever expected it to be.

script: AddBarEvent naderin_tdd_mission "Speak with the quiet man at the end of the bar" "At the end of the bar, a quiet man sits alone tapping on their Tri-Pad. They glance around from time to time, clearly waiting for something — or someone."

text:
"Finally!" He breathes a sigh of relief as you approach. "Nobody's been taking me up on this opportunity, and I've been begging for days!"

"It's just like any other dead drop. Nothing special with the location, nothing special with the package. Can't understand why nobody's taking me up on this!" There's a trace of uncertainty in their voice.

They laugh unconfidently, tapping on their Tri-Pad far too much. An act, likely just to look busy. In control. But you can see it's all bravado.

And yet, for what?

"I can arrange a payment of 75,000 credits upon completion. No deadline, as long as you make the drop. And, of course, don't be seen making it. All standard stuff. That's okay with you, right?"

text:
"You again?" He eyes you up and down as you approach. "Did you change your mind?"

They blink incredulously for a moment, before shaking their head.

"Let me remind you of the details. I'll tell you where to make the drop after you accept. There's no deadline, as long as you complete the drop. You'll receive a payment of 75,000 credits upon completion. And, of course, don't be seen doing the deed. This okay with you?"

"I can't say. Confidential until you accept."

You get the feeling they don't actually know where it's supposed to be going.

There's a moment of silence before he responds.

"Am I?" They chuckle to themselves, but nobody's smiling.

It's far too long before they respond. "I can't say anything more than I already have. Are you taking the job or not?"

text:
They slam down their Tri-Pad, staring at you with a grin that's just far too wide.

"Yes! Thank you. Thank you, thank you, thank you! You won't regret this!" There's a flurry of handshakes and tears streaming down his face, and he's far too close for comfort.

Just as the overenthusiastic handshaking begins to feel excessively excessive, he steps back a bit, perhaps realising that dribbling snot all over your shoulder isn't making the best impression on you.

"Ah. Right. You need to know where..." It's only a few taps later on his Tri-Pad that your own pings with a notification. "So, the package is on the way to your fleet. But, ah."

There's always something wrong, isn't there?

"Apologies. You'll need to contact someone over at Derinkuyu for the location of the drop. I'm just a middleman!"

You watch as they scurry off into some corner of the bar, ordering themselves a round of drinks before you can get a word in. 

It's only when your crew begins loading the package — a shielded crate of... something — onto your flagship that you begin to wonder just what you've gotten yourself into.

text:
In this day and age, only the most trusting of captains agree to deliver things without checking what they're carrying. You are not one of them.

With practiced precision, your technicians and engineers crack open the shielded crate without tripping any alarms or hidden security measures. It doesn't take long to discover a custom-built miniaturized stealth relay, folded neatly and waiting to conduct any number of nefarious schemes upon its enemies.

"Hey, watch it!" You hear your chief engineer suddenly bark over comms, overeager machinery powering down in the background. "The crate was one thing, this is another. Everyone knows these things could be rigged to explode if you touch them wrong. Plus, if we break it apart... well. Scans first."
options: naderin_tdd_examine2:Watch your crew get to work

text:
It is after a few scans (and a lecture on following protocol) that your crew discover that the relay is based on already existing designs, only with significant exterior markings and modifications on top. Non-intrusive examinations of the relay's structure are as thorough as possible, but unfortunately the crew are forced to go without the gung-ho of engineering's brand new laser powered breach cutters.

"Could've sworn... no, it's fine work, but not military. Whoever made this slapped on some exterior modifications to a common, downscaled design, which reminds me of the shortcuts you'd find apprentices make on their assessments." Your chief engineer chuckles to themselves, shaking their head a little. "I suppose this level of makeshift work could plausibly pass for spaceworthy. Not that anyone in their right mind would ever consider it up to code."

It doesn't take too long for the final report to show up on your Tri-Pad.

"Looks like this is meant to just broadcast a message," your tech officer reports to you. "What message, if any, we can only know when we make the drop."

"Oh. Okay."

That's all he says to you as you walk away.
OR
"Ah. Well. That's fine."

He returns to their Tri-Pad, tapping away for reasons only they know.

text:
Your officer taps a bit on their console, but it's clear that they already know what the danger might be about.

"There's rumours. They all seem wholly unsubstantiated, but there's something that comes up just enough that people think it could be true. It's the name, 'Kanta'."

Your ops chief chimes in from the side. "There's every chance the rumors are all fabricated. Nothing like slandering someone on the local forums to run them out of business."

"Uh, Kanta? That Kanta?" He blinks for a second, an eyebrow raised in thought. "If I were on her bad side, I'd be dead. And if I were on her good side, well, I wouldn't be here."

He swishes his bottle of cheap alcohol around idly. You don't have the impression that Remy's much of a good actor, but it's certainly possible that he's lying.

It's equally possible that you're overthinking this.

script: SetStoryOption naderin_tdd_askForMore 1 naderin_askedForMoney ui_char_spent_story_point "Convinced Remy to give you more credits to complete a dead drop"

text:
The pay might already be enough to cover anyone else's expenses, but you think you could make a pretty good case as to why you of all people deserve a little extra.

"What? Why would you need...?"

You make a few vague statements, letting Remy do all the thinking in your stead. Over a matter of minutes, you slowly see his face change several times as the gears click in his brain.

"...right, right. More credits would make sense. You need fuel and supplies, and maybe a little extra as a buffer for unforeseen damages. That'd mean this would have to be an advance on the original reward. And then add some more for delivering something nobody else wanted to deliver..."

text:
Eventually, you see the credits enter your account. 

"That's all I can give you on top of what we've already agreed on." Remy grimaces, tapping rapidly on something off screen. "Unfortunately, I now have some pressing business to attend to on account of the gaping hole in my account, so if you'll excuse me..."

Then with a swipe of his fingers, Remy cuts off the connection. It seems he'll be busy for a while yet.

You cut the comm link.

Not a minute after does an apologetic message arrive from Remy, suddenly informing you that you'll have to return to him to recieve payment, rather than immediately upon making the drop.

You get the feeling that there'll be more unforeseen complications in the future.

Remy looks up and down at you with a frown.

"What is it? Need me to wish you bright burns, and all that?" He sighs. "I don't have anything else for you. It's up to you to make the drop, whether it be this cycle or the next. And I appreciate that you've agreed to do it in place of all the other captains that've refused, but..."

They lean in, their face taking up the entire screen.

"You ARE going to make the drop, right? Eventually?"

text:
There's a sigh of relief as they lean back into their seat.

"Right, right. You aren't the kind of space captain to renege on their promises, leaving missions incomplete. I knew you were the good sort right from the start!"

Already, you see another cheap bottle of liquor being dragged out from the side. Remy takes large gulps of his drink as you ponder what to do next.

Remy blinks at you.

"Well, as long as you do it at some point, I'm happy with that. You aren't getting paid until you do it after all!"

You watch as another cheap bottle of liquor is dragged out from the side. Remy takes large gulps of his drink as you ponder what to do next.

One second of silence drags out to two, then four, then eight, then sixteen...

"You're joking, right?"

Remy shakes their head. "It was just one of them rhetorical questions anyway. Well, I have business to attend to, so burn bright captain, and I'll hopefully see you later when you've done your job. Because you will do it! Right? Right!?"

They look at you, then at the bottles strewn about behind them, then again back at you.

"Okay! Anyway, I won't keep you! Bye!" It's at that very second that they begin mashing at the cut-off button, leaving you to wonder just what crazy thoughts your silence has put in their head.
Your $shipOrFleet was recently detected - or is currently being tracked by - a nearby fleet, and dropping off the shielded crate at the specified location is extremely inadvisable.

Your nav officer reports that your $shipOrFleet has arrived at the coordinates provided by $naderin_tdd_personName.

Preparations have already been made to handle whatever trouble might come out of this dead drop - notably far more than most other drops you've done before. Ship sensors are primed, guns readied, and crew on high alert.

The $naderin_tdd_thing is held gently in a cargo drone's manipulator arms, ready for deployment. The go-button flashes softly on your command interface.

text:
The bay doors open, and the cargo drone extends its arms. Then, gently, its manipulators release.

There's a moment of bated breath as a miniaturized stealth relay unfolds itself, sliding out of the now unshielded crate. You watch the display feed as maneuvering thrusters softly glide the relay away from your flagship, and into space.

The image flickers, warbles, shakes... then nothing.

Your sensors officer looks up, a thin sheen of sweat on their forehead. "$PlayerSirOrMadam, we've lost the nav. It's gone."

text:
There's a sense of déjà vu as crew chatter quietly over comms, incredulous. Was that it? Just a souped-up civilian relay made for military-spec adventures? No trigger-happy fleets coming to claim the lives of your crew any more than usual?

"There were rumours," your sensors officer mumbles aloud to themselves. "Nobody thought it was worth the risk."

naderin_tdd_objectScanWhy:"There's something coming our way, isn't there?"

text:
Your crew exchange glances.

"As you say, $playerSirOrMadam."
"There's nothing new on sensors, $playerSirOrMadam." Your crew exchange glances as your sensors officer double-checks their work. "I can't see any reason for concern at the moment, but..."

Just as your crew begin to second-guess themselves, a garbled hyperwave burst blares out from the relay without warning. And then, as if having fulfilled its purpose, it shudders back into view of your sensors... and then breaks apart into multiple pieces.

Your comms officer taps at their console, but they appear to make no progress. "The hyperwave message is just junk. Nothing we can sift out from the static, $playerSirOrMadam."

"That relay was junk," your chief engineer scoffs from the side. "But failing like that? I can't believe I even thought it was spaceworthy."

Salvage crews depart shortly after you give the order, and results come in promptly without issue.

"Now that we were able to take a closer look, we were able to confirm that there wasn't much of a chance of it working properly in the first place. A modified relay like this? It's like self-sabotage with how shoddy the workmanship is."

Despite this, your sensors officer notes that even if the onboard electronics were turned to slag when the thing tore itself apart, the garbled hyperwave burst was certainly still strong enough to alert any nearby fleets of your presence.

text:
Dressed up in MuniSec garb, your hand-picked marines fall in line with a few actual MuniSec militia. They walk up to the ship, making a racket until the ship's crew poke their noses out to see what's going on.

It's at that time that your marines present them with a forged, but realistic illegal parking ticket, and force the entire crew out of the ship with threats of fines and imprisonment, allowing your own marines to board soon after.

Your marines' weaponry ensures that not a soul dares get any funny ideas of heroism despite the dubious legality of your 'towing operation'.

You watch on the holofeed as your marines access bridge consoles with ease, the security codes $personName provided making the process smooth sailing. As main power comes online, it takes only minutes before you see your new ship slowly begin to float free of $entity.name's spaceship gantries.

Questions from local authorities are easily answered with fabricated seizure warrants, requests for identification enthusiastically provided by the disgruntled militia from earlier, and questions from the original owner answered with messages of horrifying bureaucracy.

"Apologies ship captain, but your ship has been towed! Please follow the instructions in the letter you will receive shortly to reclaim your ship..."

After the newly liberated ship joins your fleet, you review the after-action report with $personName.

"Clean as can be, but someone's bound to figure out something's up eventually," $heOrShe sighs. "Of course, since the original owner was a bit of a knobhead, I think people will be thanking you rather than angry at you, funnily enough."

"Want to help me get some $smug_commodityName quietly moved to $smug_marketName?"

"I'm planning on moving $smug_quantity units of $smug_commodityName over to $smug_marketName, $smug_dist light-years away. It's illegal stuff, obviously, but why they want this specific brand of stuff I haven't a clue. Still, you can't let the local authorities know you're smuggling this crap if you want to get paid $smug_reward credits on delivery."

"I require $ssat_marketName monitored closely. It'll probably take a spy satellite in orbit."
OR

text:
"I need eyes on $ssat_marketName, in the $ssat_systemName. All my available assets are currently preoccupied, so a satellite in orbit would be perfect." 

$personName taps at a datapad, bringing up a holo of a spy satellite beside $himOrHer.

"Neat, huh? You can buy them from wherever if you have the right connections. Everyone with an eye and a brain will know what's up as a consequence, so make sure no patrols are tracking you when you deploy it in orbit. Do it right, and you'll get paid $ssat_reward credits. Sound good to you?"
"Someone's unfortunately found themselves on my hit list. You could do the dirty work for me, if you'd like."

"They say the independents are a faction unto themselves in the Persean Sector, but if you've seen the petty infighting I've seen, ha!" $HeOrShe shakes their head, a sense of disappointment flashing across their face.

"Suffice it to say that you're going to do some dirty work if you take me up on this... but not for anything on the level of someone's grand scheme. We're playing bit roles in the Persean Sector's crappiest soap opera, and a lot of bodies are about to get spaced."

"But, ah." $HeOrShe looks at you with a grin. "It pays pretty well, huh?"
OR
"Let's put it like this. You don't normally think about the influence of the independents in the Persean Sector, right?" $HeOrShe gestures at a softly glowing ad-holo playing theatrically behind him, punctuating $hisOrHer every sentence with exaggerated sound effects and visual cues. "After all, the big players are folk like the Hegemony. And you'd be right, all the way 'til you came down to comms me. Why? Because you're about to go blow up the little toys of the big players!"

"League patrol in the pocket of rogues? Hegemony inspector too overzealous in their search? Church patrol trying to confiscate perfectly legal scientific equipment? That's when people start calling on us, to start reminding them that the spacers of the sector can be just every bit as ruthless as the pirates they claim to protect us from."

"...well, not that I necessarily believe all that, but we'll get paid well either way. Just like I got paid to say all that," $HeOrShe adds with a sardonic laugh, flicking the ad-holo off with a dismissive gesture.

"There's a trade fleet that's rubbed certain folks the wrong way. How, we don't know, but such is their 'transgression' that they're asking me to get someone — you, should you accept — to give them the show of their lives."

$HeOrShe pulls up what looks like an internal customs inspection order, with an attached fleet disposition report. "They're in the $bcb_systemName, $bcb_dist light-years away, thanks to our tried and true tactic of holding them up for inspection. Should be plenty of room for you to get in and quietly smack them down, hopefully without ruffling too many feathers."

"But it seems that they've probably seen similar crap pulled on other captains they've known, so there's a patrol on guard to make sure they don't blow up before they leave in about $bcb_days days. It's down to you to see to it that they feel the wrath of our employer... and your paycheck. A paycheck to the tune of $bcb_reward credits, should you accept."

"Take a look at this idiot." $HeOrShe pulls up a standard ID holo of a military officer in uniform. "$bcb_targetName. Made it far too obvious they were getting paid to 'inspect' our fellow spacers. Shouldn't have been a problem if every single inspection they'd done in the past cycle hadn't mysteriously left the victims missing half of their fleet, but unfortunately $bcb_targetHeOrShe's damn well messed up. People are rightfully angry about it, and so you're going to teach $bcb_targetHimOrHer a lesson they won't forget."

"As for the details... $bcb_TargetHeOrShe's commanding a $bcb_patrolFaction patrol fleet operating out of $bcb_targetMarketName in the $bcb_systemName, $bcb_dist light-years away. You'll find $bcb_targetHimOrHer patrolling around, perhaps near a nearby jump-point, or one of their orbital strategic assets, etcetera."

$HeOrShe shuts off the ID holo, and prepares to send the details over to your flagship with a quick swipe of $hisOrHer fingers. "My, or I suppose, our client wants this poor sap spaced out of $bcb_targetHisOrHer flagship within $bcb_days days, and is willing to pay $bcb_reward credits to see it through."

$HeOrShe pulls up a clear holo taken from a popular dating service. "Ah, love. Shame this merc won't live long enough to find it. After all, just like you, $bcb_targetName's been running around doing people's dirty work. Caught involved in too many 'customs inspections', you see."

$PersonName flicks the holo away and pulls up a sector map. "We're pretty sure $bcb_targetHeOrShe's on some wild goose chase in the $bcb_systemName, $bcb_dist light-years away. Something about a weapons stash, I believe, though it does sound similar to the kind of tactics those pirates use."

"All the easier for me now that I don't have to lift a finger pulling the strings myself, sure. But I doubt whoever strung them up like this did enough of a job to keep them there for any longer than $bcb_days days. But you'll get a hefty payout of $bcb_reward credits if you complete it in time, so... sound good to you?"

"Huh." $HeOrShe clicks their tongue as their glance at their datapad. "There's a friend of mine that is, ah, shall we say, in need of extraction. There was an incident that left 'em behind bars, and they want out as soon as possible."
